reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: On the Rain-Slick Precipice of Darkness, Episode Two
Original Release: 2008
Genre Tags: RPG; Adventure; Parody; Comedy
My Overall Grade: A-
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 5-10 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Casual gamers
REVIEWOn the Rain-Slick Precipice of Darkness, Episode Two is not as challenging as the first game, but it continues the narrative and tradition of the first. It boasts solidly designed and enjoyable RPG elements, with a light and hilarious story.  This is a good pick-up for any casual RPG fans out there looking for some lighthearted fun.

Like the first game, technically, this is a parody game— but to be honest it plays better than many modern “real” RPGs that are emerging from the indie realm.  It plays like an old-school, turnbased-combat RPG, complete with leveling-up elements and a mild form of gear upgrading.  The gameplay is definitely fun and the RPG elements will keep you addicted to the progression.  You will find yourself striving to reach that next milestone of development as you play through the hilarious campaign.

On the Rain-Slick Precipice of Darkness, Episode Two is a Penny Arcade game. The story is fun and funny; it doesn’t take itself too seriously.  It is very lighthearted and the game is packed with hilarious and immature humor.  The characters are likeable, and cartoonish.  The art style is charming and fits the atmosphere of the game perfectly.  It all comes together as a very comic-like production.

This is a good second chapter to the first game.  There is really nothing drastically different in this one compared to the first, but that’s not really a bad thing because the first was pretty good.  As they say: “if it ain’t broke…”

I strongly recommend playing both Episode One and Episode Two in order and together, as they are more two parts to a whole than they are two separate games.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
Glad they didn't ♥♥♥♥ up a lot in the sequel.
The episode 2 it's pretty much the same as episode one, still lot of fun, same combat sistem but with different weapons. 'Cause the protagonist get bored of rakes and start hitting robots 'n crazy men with a hoe. Yup.

Same charming characters, same great art style, same great and yet ridiculously funny story as the first episode.

There is only one thing that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off in the gameplay: the boring yet easy  brain mini-game . Impossible to skip because a main story mission, good only to waste time and make the game look 30 minutes much longer.

Final Score: 7,5/10

Except that, the whole game is really fun, I think I said that too many times. Get this one too if you want to play the whole series!
..That now it's like the very first Final Fantasy style. Oh well, it's still nice to me.

reviewText: I love this game.  However, the developer's work ethic was weak and it shows.  Besides abandoning the series unfinished, leaving it for a different developer that mixed things up a little too much, they abandoned fixing the bugs on the Mac verision and instead removed it from the store.  Now Mac users have paid money for nothing, because the game won't even start.

reviewText: The second episode of Precipice of Darkness is a continuation of the original game and should be bought bundled with the first episode. Episode two doesn't offer any new modes of play, but still extends the fabled adventures of Tycho and Gabe along with your imported character from the first episode. If you enjoyed the first game, then episode two should be a no-brainer.

reviewText: A direct continuation of the first Rain-Slick Precipice of Darkness with all that entails.  Gameplay is generally improved, it's WAY harder to accidentally gimp yourself, and the scale (and foreshadowing) ramps up nicely.  Plus, there are some truly hysterical sequences nestled up against the creepy stuff, and it's tight enough to not overstay its welcome.

reviewText: On the Rain Slick Precipice of Darkness, Episode Two picks up shortly after the events of the first game. Once again, you (your character from the first episode can be imported) team up with 1920's-era Gabe & Tycho to stop an apocolyptic menace. Everything I said in my recommendation of the first game once again holds here, because this is pretty much the exact same game - literally, it uses the same engine, combat, mechanics, style, etc. The only things that have changed are the locations and enemies. So just take my previous review, replace slaughtering hobos
date: clowns and mimes" with "slaughtering mental patients
recommended: pretentious rich folks and giant spiders"
hoursPlayed: and there ya go. But that's not to say there's anything wrong with this - it works in an episodic format. So once again
voteText: if you are a fan of PA (their humor or characters) and adventure-RPGs
votesHelpful: despite the rough edges. I'm now looking forward to the recently announced Episode Three!"

reviewText: An even worse port than the first game, with less interesting locales and characters -- at least early on -- than Episode One. So why do I like it? The writing, of course, and the second half are both good. Also, that narrator and the style are excellent.\n\nIt's too bad Hothead Games weren't better at optimizing for computers, and that they couldn't continue the series.

reviewText: Tycho, Gabe, and you (yes YOU!) spring back into action, this time fighting the combined force of machine and black magick.\nWith unique combat system, a rather traditional point-and-click gameplay, and of course more importantly: blunt, vulgar, and hilarious comedic dialogue that we all know and love.\nTotally recommended for Penny-Arcade lovers and also non-lovers, because those who don't like Penny-Arcade can just be ♥♥♥♥♥ to sleep by dickwolves.

Part Two is a great build from the First game which takes place after the defeat of the mime god. This has the basic elements of the first game but with a continued level system ( you continue with the level you left off with from Episode One )

reviewText: Loses a lot of the JRPG focus and seems to be conflicted with trying to be a point-and-click adventure game. Tedious pixel hunting quests, overly difficult QTE combat, and a boring story with little focus really kills the potential this game had. Although it continues off from the previous game (game mechanic and level-wise), you lose all your old skills for some reason. More frustration comes from a long fetch quest chain that rewards you with a jail cell. Combat is absurd with enemies getting mountains of health plus free interrupt" heals
date: removing strategy from combat and requiring you to just pile everything onto one enemy at time. The last boss is a multi-part "gimme" fight
recommended: that ends in a lame adventure game last fight that requires no skill and cuts out your party.\n\nOverall this was really disappointing
hoursPlayed: boring and tedious. Just pick up the first one and pretend ep2 doesn't exist."

reviewText:
The gang from Penny Arcade are back in this sequel. And as such, here's a review!
Story- You return as your created character (if you wish) and in trying to rebuild your home after saving the world, Gabe and Tycho return (again destroying your house) and beg for your aid in their latest supernatural case. Again, you now travel around the city looking for a new place to live while saving the world from a tyranical (and fruit-horny robot god). Again, following the same gothic, lovecraftian style of comedy and horror, the story draws you into its world and its characters. But, as in the first game, it will only do so for a couple of hours before the credits roll. A-
Graphics- The game is exactly the same as its predicessor. Nothing truly great but works well with what it's got. D+
Sound- The voice actor for the narrator still does a terrific job and still has that dry wit. Music is recycled from the first game, not a bad thing but nothing really new either. C-
Gameplay- Still needs a controller option and still suffers the same problems. The battles are similar but the mini games that powers up the special attacks are different, which is good. Not an improvement but switches things up a bit. C
Overall- I kinda got lazy with this review but really, it is a continuation of the first game so I really can't say anything new about it. It's fun, and I like the fact that you can transfer your created character from the first game. Also, it does keep you intrested in it and makes you want to see what happens in the next episode. So... buy it and enjoy. C

reviewText:
Episode 2 done.

Hoes, Double Barrle Shotguns, Fists of Fury! Fighting MONKEYS. MECHA ROBOT BATTLE! What more could you want from a game.

Sadly, as the protagonist you are still without a place to call home. First a giant robot, then a truck. What next. You finally find a place and it gets burned down to the ground. As the anger dwells inside you the more powerful you and your hoe become!.

As you complete this episode, one thought continually crosses your mind, whats the plan, where am I going to sleep tonight.

Worth playing in my opinion. Just be sure to play through Episode 1 before picking up Episode 2. As your quest to find a bed to sleep on and shelter to keep you warm continue,

Cya next time in Ep 3.

reviewText: Penny Arcade Adventures: On the Rain-Slick Precipice of Darkness has a title that is immediately indicative of the brand of humour you'll find throughout. The writing in these games, courtesy of Penny Arcade writer Jerry Holkins, is everything you'd expect, but unfortunately you'll have to put up with a turn-based JRPG of sorts to see much of it.\nEp2 is probably the weakest of all, as the jokes are no longer enough to make the combat tedium feel quite worth it.

If there were a way to turn that off, it would be fantastic!

A very disappointing sequel. Unlike the first episode, the writing in Episode Two is poor and features an overabundance of the F word, not to be funny, but used as a filler word in every f'ing sentences. It retains the same crass humour, but it's much less successful than the first game. However, the time-based QTE's during battle sequences have been altered and now feels slightly less repetitive than in Episode One.\n\nIn any case, you should start with Episode One, it's an excellent game. And if you really like it, you may enjoy Episode Two as well.
Somewhat longer, but ultimately very similar , perhaps TOO much, to Episode 1. Writing is still very good, albeit somewhat toned down into more down-to-earth" as opposed to mad god babbling
date: main characters are still as funny as ever and this time we actually get to know who the villain is prior to the very climax of the game. One MAJOR drawback is that Episode 2 is heavy on hinting towards Episode 3 which will unfortunately never come. Unlocked Insane mode might get you to replay it just to open those damned chests."

reviewText: The only possible reason you should not play this game is if you haven't played Episode 1.\n\nIf thats the case, go play that!

PoD Ep 2 is Ep 1 with more of everything. If you enjoyed Ep 1, you'll enjoy Ep 2, although how you enjoy it is questionable. The game is about an hour longer than the first but there are still three major areas (don't believe the map). The Special moves are harder to pull off and require more practice as well. The difficulty curve is fine tuned as well to be a lot more steady as compared to the first which I really enjoyed. Once again, play this game without looking anything up first.

That said, the loading times are unforgivable (a minute if not more). The first game had barely any load times and this game (I believe) runs on the same engine and to make matters worse, you'll be going between areas A LOT. Plus, the game is still short. The final boss is a puzzle boss and anticlimatic at best, not at all like the boss from the last game.

Although RPG lovers will enjoy this game more easily than the first game, it feels a little more disappointing. Still a fun game though.

Starts off a bit oddly by not really explaining how tycho, gabe, and yourself split ways to begin with, but quickly gets back into the swing of things with the same silliness and absurdity of the first. Doesn't differ much from the first episode in either structure or combat, but still quite fun. If you liked the first one grab this one too.

The best point and click adventure I ever played,
AWESOME AS WELL AS EP 1
Highly recommanded
Part 2 of an awesome game.

The sequel to Episode One!\nI found that this was easier than episode one, but the battles were longer to work through. Still very fun with plenty of humor. I think it obvious that if you liked and played the first one, then this one is for you. Not recomended if you did not play the first one, especially for some of the story elements.
Very smart and entertaining, a must have for Penny Arcade and Ron Gilbert fans. It's a pity the serie is over.
I really like the ridiculous stylings of this game, and the combat can be kind of fun if you're good at getting the combos and quick-time bonuses.

Episode 2 of On the Rain Slick Precipice of Darkness continues the eldritch adventures of Tycho, Gabe, and your character from the first episode in their quest to avert catastrophe at the hands of giant robots with an obscene attraction towards fruit. As expected, it follows most of the conventions established in the first game as far as adventuring and combat goes, with only a few minor changes in terms of item function and cast. Overall, a good game for anyone looking for an adventure of only a few hours or for those who enjoy the style and humor of the Penny Arcade webcomic.\n\nAs of mid-2012 (around the time of Episode 3's release), numerous players on Windows 7 machines were reporting being unable to get past the games start menu. Although neither Hothead Games nor Steam Support were able to help assauge this problem, it ultimately proved to be solvable by running it in compatibility mode with Windows 95.

The sequel to episode 1 and I have to say, MOVE OUTTA WAY STICK OF TRUTH!!! AN OLD TIMER IS HITTING THE STREET!!!\nYeah I don't like the stick of truth, but no offence this game and episode 1 is WAY better than the stick of truth, The game macanics (Message me if i spelt it wrong) are the same from episode 1: Create you charater, Battle enemies and Watch you charater in 2D cutscenes, I give this game 10/10

Episode 2 continues where Episode 1 left the player. This time there is a bit more interesting plot and everything seems to be polished/fixed from first episode (characters, jokes, abilities, gameplay, plot, attacks, upgrades, you name it). If you made it through Episode 1 you'll like this one for sure.
Another of the best Adventure games ever made. It's a real shame the third will never be finished.
Yes, they made a game with Penny Arcade characters.  Plays like Mario RPG.
A nice mix of adventure and role-playing game in a twisted, crazy steampunk world with unique cartoon graphics. This game is truly a masterpiece. Pity there are no other episodes.
